How to Teach Gratitude

Paige Abramson Hirsch, Teacher + Education Consultant + Parent

Ages
4-5,
5-6
Critical Thinking
Social + Emotional
“Gratitude is not just a feeling outside your control that arrives willy-nilly. It’s more like a radio channel: you can choose at any time to tune in.”

-Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence

Learn

Basic Concepts

The benefits of gratitude are backed by science. There are many compelling reasons to create and sustain a focus on gratitude, especially for our children. Psychology professor and the world’s leading scientific expert on gratitude, Dr. Robert Emmons, cites benefits that affect both the mind and body:

  • Magnifies positive emotions
  • Increases happiness and optimism levels
  • Reduces stress levels
  • Increases self-worth
  • Improves physical and psychological health
  • Improves sleep
  • Decreases envy, greed, and bitterness
  • Enhances empathy

Gratitude is a state of mind that doesn’t depend on one’s life circumstances. It’s a “state of mind that arises when you affirm a good thing in your life that comes from outside yourself, or when you notice and relish little pleasures.” -Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence

Do

Core Marbles

  • Teach the concept of “enough”
  • Model gratitude
  • Create gratitude routines

Build a Gratitude Practice
  • Teach the concept of “enough”.
    • In a world of overconsumption, grown-ups have to make a conscious decision to work against the bombarding message of more, more, more on our children. Teaching the concept of “enough” shows a child that more is not always necessary.
      • When your child says some version of “I want [insert toy name)]”, gently say, “You have enough markers / dolls / trucks / costumes. We don’t need any more.”
    • Organically inserting the word “enough” into your daily conversations will help your child re-focus on what they have (vs. what they do not have).
  • Model gratitude.
    • First, how grateful are you? Make an effort to build your own gratitude practice. Be mindful about it. Your child is likely picking up on your many conscious or subconscious cues.
    • Regularly express gratitude. Seemingly simple, but share often and your child will come to see this as natural and part of their manners.
      • “We are so lucky to live in a city with so many amazing parks. I love playing in the park with you.”
      • “That water got hot so fast. We’re really lucky to have water so available. It’s not like that everywhere – remember the The Water Princess story we just read?”
      • “I’m so grateful that Tia June was able to take you to soccer practice today. It’s so nice to have friends and family who can help us when we need it.”
      • “Wow, the sky is so blue today; it’s beautiful!”
      • “I’m so thankful for being invited to a birthday dinner for my friend.”
  • Create gratitude routines.
    • Family gratitude list – Create a space where any member of the family can record what they are grateful for on a list, at any time. Keep it in a high-traffic area – on the fridge, on a whiteboard. Include little and big things – a tasty bite of food, someone smiling when they open a door, a thank you note, etc.
    • Gratitude notes – Take time to write Thank You notes. It’s a simple and effective way of teaching a child to express gratitude – not just to feel grateful. Encourage your child to express Thank You to anyone, everyone, that makes their everyday. From the mail to groceries to teachers, show your child that there are real people with real lives behind many seemingly mundane aspects of their everyday.
      • Quick and easy printable Thank You cards make it fun (and double-down on fine motor practice).
      • Send a letter / postcard to a friend or family member. Free printable here!
    • Gratitude journal – Write it down. Each child can write down three things they are grateful for each morning or at bedtime; it’s a nice way to either begin or a end a day. Early writers can give it a go with best-guess spelling, pre-writers can dictate to you so they can re-read what they’re grateful for. Make it easier with these journals – #1, #2.
    • Go outside, go on a nature walk – Fun and simple idea for a gratitude-infused nature walk.
    • Practice growth mindset skills – Our favorite activity kit.
    • Develop a sense for the value of money – Spend, save, give, invest.
“Piglet noticed that even though he had a very small heart, it could hold a rather large amount of gratitude.”

-A.A. Milne

Our Favorite Books on this Topic

For Younger Children

  • I’m Thankful Each Day
  • The Thankful Book
  • Gracias / Thanks
  • Bear Says Thanks
  • Thankful

For Older Children

  • Grateful: A Song of Giving Thanks
  • Carmela Full of Wishes
  • Bear and Wolf
  • Secret of Saying Thanks
  • The Water Princess
  • We Are Grateful: Otsaliheliga

For Grown-ups

  • Gratitude and Kindness
Share Favorite Print

What is your child grateful for today? Share with us!

Paige Abramson Hirsch, Teacher + Education Consultant + Parent

Paige Abramson Hirsch is an elementary school teacher turned lawyer turned educational administrator who currently works as an educational consultant supporting school districts and charter schools. Paige studied psychology with a focus in child development at Tufts University and holds a JD/M.Ed from the University of Minnesota. Paige also serves on the Board of the non-profit HAND. She lives in San Carlos, California with her husband and two young children, whom she thanks for providing her with endless opportunities to analyze child development and behavior!
